Knowledge Point: As these examples show, ananake may occur after the verb in the subject position as in \REF{ex:4.63}, but also before the verb as in \REF{ex:4.64}, or at the end of the clause as in \REF{ex:4.65}.
Content 1: \gll He nonoho rō \ꞌai \textbf{ananake} \ꞌi \ꞌOhovehi. | \gls NTR PL:stay EMPH SUBS together at Ohovehi | \glt ‘They lived together in Ohovehi.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌI tū hora era \textbf{ananake} i u\ꞌi ai rū\ꞌau rima kore. | \gls at DEM time DIST together PFV look PVP old_woman hand lack | \glt ‘At that moment they all (together) saw that the old woman had no hands.’
Content 3: \gll He \ꞌamo te \ꞌura \textbf{ananake}. | \gls NTR carry ART lobster together | \glt ‘Together they carried the lobsters.’

Knowledge Point: Regardless of its position in the clause, ananake always refers to the subject. For example, \REF{ex:4.65} does not mean ‘they carried all the lobsters’. Now this also has a semantic reason: ananake normally has human reference; it is uncommon for ananake\is{ananake ‘together’} to be used for animals or inanimate things.
Content 1: \gll He \ꞌamo te \ꞌura \textbf{ananake}. | \gls NTR carry ART lobster together | \glt ‘Together they carried the lobsters.’

Knowledge Point: Prenominal ananake is never preceded by a preposition. Even so, the examples show that it may occur in noun phrases with a variety of functions, for example subject as in \REF{ex:4.68}, locational\is{Locational} adjunct as in \REF{ex:4.69}, or temporal adjunct as in \REF{ex:4.70}. But ananake\is{ananake ‘together’} te N is especially common with nouns denoting place or time, as in (\ref{ex:4.69}–\ref{ex:4.70}), a construction that has been taken over by paurō\is{paurō ‘every’} te N nowadays.

Content 4: \gll He oho tau nuahine era \textbf{ananake} te motu. | \gls NTR go DEM old_woman DIST all ART islet | \glt ‘The old woman went to all the islets.’

Other children learn Rapa Nui dancing, yet others dancing the cueca.’

Knowledge Point: The determiner can be left out, as in \REF{ex:4.90} above:

Subsubsection: \is{mee rahi ‘many’@me{\ꞌe rahi ‘many’|(\textit{Me{\ꞌe rahi: from noun phrase to quantifier\label{sec:4.4.7.1
Knowledge Point: \textit{me{\ꞌ}e rahi} may occur in non-initial noun phrases with different semantic roles, as in (\ref{ex:4.91}–\ref{ex:4.93}) above.
Content 1: \gll Ko \ꞌamo \ꞌana \textbf{me\ꞌe} \textbf{rahi} \textbf{nō} \textbf{atu} \ꞌati. | \gls PRF carry CONT thing many/much just away problem | \glt ‘They have carried many kinds of sufferings.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌI te kona nei i noho ai \textbf{me\ꞌe} \textbf{rahi} \textbf{mahana}. | \gls at ART place PROX PFV stay PVP thing many/much day | \glt ‘In this place this stayed many days.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Adverb} Rahi\is{rahi ‘much/many’} often serves as adverb\is{Adverb}, modifying a verb or adjective: ‘a lot, very (much)’. When modifying a verb, rahi often implies quantification of the subject or object of the verb (in the same way as tahi ‘all’, \sectref{sec:4.4.9}). E.g. in \REF{ex:4.98}, rahi does not refer to many acts of seeing, but quantifies the object of seeing.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌIna he take\ꞌa \textbf{rahi} i te taŋata. | \gls NEG NTR see many/much ACC ART man | \glt ‘He did not see many people.’

Knowledge Point: In fact, this is the same construction as \textit{me{\ꞌ}e rahi} when used as a noun phrase (see (\ref{ex:4.87}–\ref{ex:4.89}) above).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Me\ꞌe} \textbf{rahi} te manu o ruŋa. | \gls thing many/much ART bird of above | \glt ‘There were many birds (lit. many [were] the birds) on (the island).’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Me\ꞌe} \textbf{rahi} te taŋata [i mate \ꞌi rā noho iŋa]. | \gls thing many/much ART man ~PFV die at DIST stay NMLZ | \glt ‘Many people died (lit. many [were] the people who died) at that time.’

Knowledge Point: Tahi may have reference to an O argument as in \REF{ex:4.117}, an S argument as in \REF{ex:4.118}, or an A argument as in \REF{ex:4.119}:
Content 1: \gll He haka hāŋai \textbf{tahi} i tū māmoe era. | \gls NTR CAUS feed all ACC DEM sheep DIST | \glt ‘We fed all the sheep.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌArīnā he turu \textbf{tahi} mai tātou. | \gls today.FUT NTR go_down all hither 1PL.INCL | \glt ‘Today we all go down (to the school).’
Content 3: \gll He tike\ꞌa \textbf{tahi} te ŋā poki i te pahī tu\ꞌu iho mai. | \gls NTR see all ART PL child ACC ART ship arrive just_then hither | \glt ‘The children all saw the ship that had just arrived.’

Knowledge Point: Sentential adverbs occur in different positions in the clause. For example, while \textit{tako{\ꞌ}a} ‘also’ as a sentential adverb is usually clause-initial (see \REF{ex:4.134} below), pēaha ‘perhaps’ occurs after the initial constituent as in \REF{ex:4.127}:
Content 1: \gll Te hua\ꞌai o Iovani, ko \ꞌite \ꞌā ta\ꞌe he hua\ꞌai o rāua te hua\ꞌai o Tiare. \textbf{Tako\ꞌa}, \ꞌina a Iovani kai māhani hia ki a Tiare. | \gls NTR family of Iovani PRF know CONT CONNEG PRED family of 3PL ART family of Tiare also NEG PROP Iovani NEG.PFV accustomed yet to PROP Tiare | \glt ‘Iovani’s family knew that Tiare’s family was not related to them. Also, Iovani did not know Tiare yet.’
Content 2: \gll Ku toke \ꞌā \textbf{pēaha} to tāua tāropa \ꞌura. | \gls PRF steal CONT perhaps ART:of 1DU.INCL basket lobster | \glt ‘Our basket of lobsters seems to have been stolen.’

Knowledge Point: Iho has moved to the adverb\is{Adverb} position, directly after the verb. As a result, iho occurs before rō and nō (unlike directionals, see the chart in \sectref{sec:7.1}) and may co-occur with directionals\is{Directional} (see \REF{ex:4.129} below).
Content 1: \gll Tutu\ꞌu \textbf{iho} nō mai te ŋā poki \ꞌi \ꞌaŋataiahi. | \gls PL:arrive just_then just hither ART PL child at yesterday | \glt ‘The children arrived just yesterday.’

Knowledge Point: Iho indicates that an event takes place exactly at, or just prior to, the time of reference. This often implies that something will happen only at the time specified, not earlier. In a perfective clause, this means that the event has just happened: ‘recently, just’; in other aspects, iho can be translated as ‘just at that moment, exactly then’. When iho occurs in a main clause with perfective sense, the aspectual tends to be left out, as \REF{ex:4.129} shows.
Content 1: \gll Tutu\ꞌu \textbf{iho} nō mai te ŋā poki \ꞌi \ꞌaŋataiahi. | \gls PL:arrive just_then just hither ART PL child at yesterday | \glt ‘The children arrived just yesterday.’

Knowledge Point: In these examples, \textit{tako{\ꞌ}a} indicates that the event or action applies not only to an entity mentioned previously, but to another entity as well, e.g. a different subject as in \REF{ex:4.132}, or a different object as in \REF{ex:4.133}.

Knowledge Point: When hoki connects two clauses, it is usually added to the first constituent of the second clause. This is normally the verb phrase as in \REF{ex:4.139}, but it may be a preposed constituent as in \REF{ex:4.140}:
Content 1: \gll He to\ꞌo mai te nui, he \ꞌakaveŋa. [He to\ꞌo mai \textbf{hoki}] te \ꞌiti, he \ꞌakaveŋa tako\ꞌa. | \gls NTR take hither ART big ART carry_on_back ~NTR take hither also ART small NTR carry_on_back also | \glt ‘The oldest (girl) took (the food) and carried it on her back. The youngest also took (food) and also carried it on her back.’
Content 2: \gll He to\ꞌo mai i te \ꞌō\ꞌone... [Hai moa \textbf{hoki}] ana to\ꞌo mai. | \gls NTR take hither ACC ART soil ~INS chicken also IRR take hither | \glt ‘He took dirt... He also took a chicken.’

Knowledge Point: Clauses such as (\ref{ex:4.145}–\ref{ex:4.146}) could be labeled “presentational”: \textit{{\ꞌ}ī} followed by a nominal constituent serves to signal the presence of someone or something.\footnote{\label{fn:201}This does not mean that \textit{{\ꞌ}ī} is a general device to express presentational clauses, e.g. to introduce participants in narrative (on presentational clauses, see \citealt[4]{Bailey2009}). The use of \textit{{\ꞌ}ī} in presentational clauses is limited to deictic contexts, where the entity presented is visible to speaker and hearer.}
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\ꞌĪ} au. | \gls IMM 1SG | \glt ‘Here I am.’
Content 2: \gll Ka e\ꞌa koe, \textbf{\ꞌī} tu\ꞌu pāpā era \ꞌi haho. | \gls IMP go_out 2SG IMM POSS.2SG.O father DIST at outside | \glt ‘Go outside, here is your father outside.’

Knowledge Point: More generally, \textit{{\ꞌ}ī} expresses simultaneity\is{Simultaneity} with respect to a time of reference. In \REF{ex:4.147} above the time of reference is the present; in narrative discourse the time of reference is the time when events in the context take place. In combination with perfect aspect\is{Aspect!perfect} \textit{ko V {\ꞌ}ā}\is{ko V {\ꞌ}ā (perfect aspect)}, \textit{{\ꞌ}ī} underlines that an event has just taken place.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\ꞌĪ} au he oho rō \ꞌai mai ta\ꞌe pō. | \gls IMM 1SG NTR go EMPH SUBS from CONNEG night | \glt ‘I’m going now, before it gets dark.’

Knowledge Point: Often \textit{{\ꞌ}ī}\is{i (deictic)@{\ꞌ}ī (deictic)} occurs in combination with a perception verb. \textit{{\ꞌ}Ī} has the effect of putting the perceived object into focus\is{Focus}. What the participant sees or hears is something significant or even surprising. The act of perception may also be implied, as in \REF{ex:4.152}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\ꞌĪ} ka o\ꞌo atu ena, e ha\ꞌuru nō \ꞌā a Makita. | \gls IMM CNTG enter away MED IPFV sleep just CONT PROP Makita | \glt ‘He entered, and (look!) Makita was sleeping.’

Knowledge Point: As (\ref{ex:4.149}–\ref{ex:4.151}) show, the subject of the clause tends to be placed straight after \textit{{\ꞌ}ī}, before the verb (\sectref{sec:8.6.1.1}. This is not obligatory, though.
Content 1: \gll E Pea ē, \textbf{\ꞌī} a Kava e taŋi mai nei ki a au, mai te pō\ꞌā ki te hora nei. | \gls VOC Pea VOC IMM PROP Kava IPFV cry hither PROX to PROP 1SG from ART morning to ART time PROX | \glt ‘Pea, (listen,) Kava is crying for me, from morning till now.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\ꞌĪ} a Vai Ora ka u\ꞌi atu ena, \ꞌina a Tahoŋa. | \gls IMM PROP Vai Ora CNTG look away MED NEG PROP Tahonga | \glt ‘Vai Ora looked: Tahonga wasn’t there!’

Knowledge Point: (\ref{ex:4.154}–\ref{ex:4.155}) are presentational clauses, which indicate the presence of an entity in the distance, just like \textit{{\ꞌ}ī} presents entities nearby.\footnote{\label{fn:202}This use led \citet[319]{Fischer2001Hispan} to take \textit{{\ꞌ}ai} as derived from \ili{Spanish} existential marker hay. However, the use of \textit{{\ꞌ}ai} to introduce presentational clauses already occurs in old texts.} As \REF{ex:4.154} shows, initial \textit{{\ꞌ}ai} may be followed by another \textit{{\ꞌ}ai} at the end of the clause, just like \textit{{\ꞌ}ī} may be followed by clause-final \textit{{\ꞌ}ī a{\ꞌ}a}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\ꞌAi} a Toroa \ꞌai. \textbf{\ꞌAi} a Feripe \ꞌai. | \gls there PROP Toroa there there PROP Felipe there | \glt ‘There is Toroa (=Father Seb. Englert). There is Felipe.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\ꞌAi} tu\ꞌu tao\ꞌa ko haka topa \ꞌā e te kape pahī \ꞌi tū hora nei. | \gls there POSS.2SG.O object PRF CAUS descend CONT AG ART captain ship at DEM time PROX | \glt ‘There are your belongings, which have just been disembarked by the captain of the ship.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{\ꞌAi} a Toroa \ꞌai. \textbf{\ꞌAi} a Feripe \ꞌai. | \gls there PROP Toroa there there PROP Felipe there | \glt ‘There is Toroa (=Father Seb. Englert). There is Felipe.’

Knowledge Point: As \REF{ex:4.160} shows, nā may be reinforced by another nā\is{na (demonstrative)@nā (demonstrative)!deictic} at the end of the clause.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌĒ, ka iri mai koe, \textbf{nā} te vave \textbf{nā}. | \gls hey IMP ascend hither 2SG MED ART wave MED | \glt ‘Hey, come up, there is a wave!’

Knowledge Point: \paragraph{\textit{Pa{\ꞌ}i} ‘in fact’}\label{sec:4.5.4.2.1} \textit{Pa{\ꞌ}i} \is{pai ‘in fact’@pa{\ꞌ}i ‘in fact’|(}is used to link clauses, indicating that the clause in some way builds upon, confirms or reinforces the preceding clause. In \REF{ex:4.161}, \textit{\mbox{pa{\ꞌ}i}} (2x) confirms what the other speaker has said. In \REF{ex:4.162}, a fragment from an oral text, \textit{pa{\ꞌ}i} appears to be sprinkled throughout the discourse without a very specific function.
Content 1: \gll —¿Ta\ꞌe \ꞌō mai \ꞌAnakena i haka eke ai? —\ꞌĒē, \textbf{pa\ꞌi}. —\ꞌI \ꞌAnakena \textbf{pa\ꞌi} tū hora ena i haka eke ai. | \gls ~~~~~CONNEG really from Anakena PFV CAUS go_up PVP ~~~~yes~~~ in_fact ~~~~at Anakena in_fact DEM time DIST PFV CAUS go_up PVP | \glt ‘—Didn’t they take (the statue) up from Anakena? —Yes, indeed. —Indeed, when they took it up, it was in Anakena.’
Content 2: \gll He \ꞌaroha atu \textbf{pa\ꞌi} ki a kōrua, \ꞌiorana \textbf{pa\ꞌi} a kōrua ta\ꞌato\ꞌa. \ꞌI te me\ꞌe, ko haŋa \ꞌā \textbf{pa\ꞌi} a au mo vānaŋa atu ki a koe... | \gls NTR greet away in_fact to PROP 2PL hello in_fact PROP 2PL all at ART thing PRF want CONT in_fact PROP 1SG for talk away to PROP 2SG | \glt ‘I’m greeting \textit{pa{\ꞌ}i} you; hello \textit{pa{\ꞌ}i} to you all. Because, I want \textit{pa{\ꞌ}i} to talk to you...’

Knowledge Point: \paragraph{\textit{Ho{\ꞌ}i} ‘indeed’}\label{sec:4.5.4.2.2} \textit{Ho{\ꞌ}i}\is{hoi@ho{\ꞌ}i ‘in fact’|(} gives (some) emphasis to the preceding constituent. It is used after a wide range of elements, such as deictic particles \REF{ex:4.165} and the negation \textit{{\ꞌ}ina} \REF{ex:4.166}. Like \textit{pa{\ꞌ}i}, it may have a confirmatory function: ‘indeed’ \REF{ex:4.167}.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌAi \textbf{ho\ꞌi} te taŋata e ha\ꞌamata era e tari era ki ruŋa i te pahī. | \gls there indeed ART person IPFV begin DIST IPFV carry DIST to above at ART ship | \glt ‘Then \textit{ho{\ꞌ}i} the people started to be transported on board the ship.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌIna \textbf{ho\ꞌi} koe ko riri. He kori nō ho\ꞌi nei me\ꞌe. | \gls NEG indeed 2SG PROM angry PRED play just indeed PROX thing | \glt ‘Don’t \textit{ho{\ꞌ}i} be angry. This is just a joke.’
Content 3: \gll —¿He \ꞌariki ho\ꞌi rā? —\ꞌĒē, \textbf{ho\ꞌi}. | \gls ~~~~~PRED king indeed INTENS ~~~~yes~~~ indeed | \glt ‘—Is that a king/chief? —Yes, indeed.’

Knowledge Point: The particle ia\is{ia ‘then’|(} ‘so, then’ is a transition marker. It occurs in modern Rapa Nui only.\footnote{\label{fn:204}Ia may be a borrowing from \ili{Tahitian}: \ili{Tahitian} ia is “un anaphorique général qui renvoie d’une manière assez vague à ce qui précède, thème antéposé ou, plus généralement, contexte antérieur” (a general anaphoric which refers in a rather vague way to what precedes, a preposed theme or, more generally, the preceding context, \citealt[118]{LazardPeltzer2000}).} When the clause starts with a verb phrase, ia occurs after the verb phrase; \REF{ex:4.170} shows that it occurs after the VP{}-final particle \textit{{\ꞌ}ana}:
Content 1: \gll Ko koa atu \ꞌana \textbf{ia} a Tamy \ꞌi tū hora era. | \gls PRF happy away CONT then PROP Tamy at DEM time DIST | \glt ‘Tamy was happy at that moment.’

Knowledge Point: When the verb phrase is not initial in the clause, ia occurs either after the first constituent as in \REF{ex:4.171}, or after the verb phrase as in \REF{ex:4.172}.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌAi \textbf{ia} e raŋaraŋa mai era... | \gls there then IPFV float:RED hither DIST | \glt ‘Then he floated...’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌI tū hora era he ŋaro\ꞌa \textbf{ia} e \ꞌUri\ꞌuri i te ora. | \gls at DEM time DIST NTR perceive then AG Uri’uri ACC ART life | \glt ‘At that moment, Uri’uri felt relieved.’

Knowledge Point: Ia indicates that the event in the clause develops from events mentioned before. It may be the result of, or dependent on, other events (‘so, thus’), as in \REF{ex:4.173} below. In a weaker sense it marks events which are simply subsequent to other events (‘then’), or marks the apodosis of conditional clauses as in \REF{ex:4.174}.
Content 1: \gll He ha\ꞌamata \textbf{ia} te moto \ꞌi tū ŋā poki era. | \gls NTR begin then ART fight at DEM PL child DIST | \glt ‘(Some boys mocked Taparahi and he got angry.) So a fight started between the boys.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌE mo ai ō\ꞌona he repahoa ō\ꞌou, e Okū ē, he repahoa tako\ꞌa \textbf{ia} ō\ꞌoku! | \gls and if exist POSS.3SG.O PRED friend POSS.2SG.O VOC Oku VOC PRED friend also then POSS.1SG.O | \glt ‘And if he is your friend, Oku, then he is also my friend!’

Knowledge Point: The intensifying particle rā\footnote{\label{fn:205}The etymology of rā is unknown, but it is probably related to \ili{Tahitian} rā, which also occurs after the first clause constituent. Tahitian rā is a contrastive conjunction\is{Conjunction} ‘but’, but also serves as an intensifier in commands and conditional clauses\is{Clause!conditional} (\citealt[98]{LazardPeltzer2000}; \citealt[399]{AcadémieTahitienne1999}).} (not to be confused with demonstrative rā) occurs in content questions\is{Question!content} and imperatives\is{Imperative}. It is placed after the first constituent of the clause; in questions this is the question phrase, in imperatives\is{Imperative} the verb phrase.\footnote{\label{fn:206}Rā itself is not part of the verb phrase: in \REF{ex:4.176} it occurs after the direction mai; in \REF{ex:4.177} it occurs after the VP{}-final particle \textit{{\ꞌ}ana}.} Rā occurs after the verb phrase-final particle \textit{{\ꞌ}ana} as in \REF{ex:4.177}, but before other sentence-level particles like ia ‘then’, as in \REF{ex:4.178}.
Content 1: \gll Ka noho \ꞌiti\ꞌiti mai \textbf{rā} koe. | \gls IMP stay little:RED hither INTENS 2SG | \glt ‘You wait a little.’
Content 2: \gll ¿E aha \ꞌana \textbf{rā} koe? | \gls ~IPFV what CONT INTENS 2SG | \glt ‘What are you doing?’
Content 3: \gll ¿E aha \ꞌana \textbf{rā} koe? | \gls ~IPFV what CONT INTENS 2SG | \glt ‘What are you doing?’
Content 4: \gll ¿Ko ai \textbf{rā} ia koe? | \gls ~PROM who INTENS then 2SG | \glt ‘Who then are you?’

Knowledge Point: It is also used in non-rhetorical questions, to which the speaker expects a reply. Rā conveys a certain vividness and inquisitiveness: the speaker is eager to get an answer. \REF{ex:4.180}, for example, is spoken by a curious child. \REF{ex:4.181} is spoken by one (teenage) friend to another.
Content 1: \gll ¿A hē nei \textbf{rā} i ŋaro ai?~... ¿\ꞌI hē \textbf{rā} e noho era tō\ꞌona ŋā repahoa era? | \gls ~toward CQ PROX INTENS PFV disappear PVP ~at CQ INTENS IPFV stay DIST POSS.3SG.O PL friend DIST | \glt ‘Where did (the fish) disappear? Where do its friends live?’
Content 2: \gll ¿Pē hē \textbf{rā} koe, e Hiero ē? | \gls ~like CQ INTENS 2SG VOC Hiero VOC | \glt ‘How are you, Hiero?’

Knowledge Point: A question like \REF{ex:4.181}, with its somewhat insistent tone, is only appropriate when talking to friends or close acquaintances. When speaking to strangers, one would use the more neutral ¿Pē hē koe? ‘How are you?’ (Nancy Weber, p.c.).
Content 1: \gll ¿Pē hē \textbf{rā} koe, e Hiero ē? | \gls ~like CQ INTENS 2SG VOC Hiero VOC | \glt ‘How are you, Hiero?’

Knowledge Point: When rā\is{ra (intensifier)@rā (intensifier)} is used in imperative\is{Imperative} clauses, it marks insistence as well. The context may involve a certain emotion: enthusiasm as in \REF{ex:4.182}, defy as in \REF{ex:4.183}:
Content 1: \gll Ka u\ꞌi mai \textbf{rā} koe. Ko rava\ꞌa \ꞌā e au e rima tara. | \gls IMP look hither INTENS 2SG PRF obtain CONT AG 1SG NUM five peso | \glt ‘Look at me. I found five pesos!’
Content 2: \gll ¡Ka kī mai \textbf{rā} \ꞌa \ꞌai a koe i pu\ꞌa atu! | \gls ~IMP say hither INTENS of.A who PROP 2SG PFV beat away | \glt ‘(Soldiers are mocking Jesus:) Now tell us who hit you!’

Knowledge Point: In combination with a PND\is{Demonstrative!postnominal}, the t{}-demonstrative has \textsc{anaphoric}\is{Anaphora} function: it signals that the entity referred to has been mentioned in the preceding context (and, by implication, is known to the hearer). In \REF{ex:4.192}, there are three referents: Ure a Ohovehi, the boat and the men. All have been mentioned before, and all are referred to with the same combination of a t{}-demonstrative and a PND\is{Demonstrative!postnominal}.
Content 1: \gll He tike\ꞌa e \textbf{tau} kope \textbf{era}, ko Ure \ꞌa Ohovehi, \textbf{tau} vaka \textbf{era} o \textbf{tau} ŋāŋata \textbf{era}. | \gls NTR see AG DEM person DIST PROM Ure a Ohovehi DEM boat DIST of DEM men DIST | \glt ‘That man Ure a Ohovehi saw that boat of those people.’

Knowledge Point: As demonstratives\is{Demonstrative} are the main anaphoric\is{Anaphora} device to track participants in discourse, they are much more common than \ili{English} demonstratives\is{Demonstrative}. \is{tu (demonstrative determiner)@tū (demonstrative determiner)}Example \REF{ex:4.192} would sound unnatural in translation if all the demonstratives\is{Demonstrative} were translated by demonstratives\is{Demonstrative}.\footnote{\label{fn:214}See \citet[21]{Englert1978}: “El artícula tou-era (a veces tau-era) es pronombre demostrativo que se usa frequentemente como simple artículo definido.” (The article tou-era (sometimes tau-era) is a demonstratie pronoun which is often used simply as a definite article.)}
Content 1: \gll He tike\ꞌa e \textbf{tau} kope \textbf{era}, ko Ure \ꞌa Ohovehi, \textbf{tau} vaka \textbf{era} o \textbf{tau} ŋāŋata \textbf{era}. | \gls NTR see AG DEM person DIST PROM Ure a Ohovehi DEM boat DIST of DEM men DIST | \glt ‘That man Ure a Ohovehi saw that boat of those people.’

Knowledge Point: As discussed in \sectref{sec:4.6.2}, PNDs\is{Demonstrative!postnominal} are obligatory when the noun is preceded by a t{}-de\-mon\-stra\-tive (tau/tou/tū\is{tu (demonstrative determiner)@tū (demonstrative determiner)}), unless the noun phrase contains the identity marker \textit{{\ꞌ}ā}/\textit{{\ꞌ}ana}. PNDs also occur in combination with other determiners: articles\is{te (article)} as in \REF{ex:4.195}, possessive pronouns\is{Pronoun!possessive} as in \REF{ex:4.196}:
Content 1: \gll te kona hare \textbf{era} | \gls ART place house DIST | \glt ‘home’
Content 2: \gll tō\ꞌona koro \textbf{era} | \gls POSS.3SG.O Dad DIST | \glt ‘his father’

Knowledge Point: Like tau/tou/tū\is{tu (demonstrative determiner)@tū (demonstrative determiner)} N era, it may be used to refer to participants in a story who have been mentioned before. In \REF{ex:4.201}, tau poki era and te poki era refer to the same child:
Content 1: \gll He oŋa mai \textbf{tau} \textbf{poki} \textbf{era} o tau taŋata era ko Kava te Rūruki. He tikera \textbf{te} \textbf{poki} \textbf{era}... | \gls NTR appear hither DEM child DIST of DEM man DIST PROM Kava te Ruruki NTR see ART child DIST | \glt ‘The child of that man Kava te Ruruki observed him. The child saw it...’

Knowledge Point: Te\is{te (article)} N era may also refer to things which have not been previously mentioned, but which are definite because they are explained in the noun phrase itself: a modifying phrase or relative clause\is{Clause!relative} after the noun specifies what the noun refers to. In \REF{ex:4.204} below, the referent of te haŋa era ‘the bay’ is specified by the genitive phrase \textit{o {\ꞌ}Akahaŋa}; in \REF{ex:4.205} \textit{te ha{\ꞌ}u era} ‘the hats’ is explained by the relative clause\is{Clause!relative} e aŋa era hai rau toa ‘made with sugarcane leaves’.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌI mu\ꞌa i \textbf{te} \textbf{haŋa} \textbf{era} o \ꞌAkahaŋa, te noho haŋa ō\ꞌona. | \gls at front at ART bay DIST of Akahanga ART stay NMLZ POSS.3SG.O | \glt ‘His residence was in front of the bay of Akahanga.’
Content 2: \gll O rā hora \ꞌā te ŋā vi\ꞌe o nei pa\ꞌari era e hatu rō \ꞌana i \textbf{te} \textbf{ha\ꞌu} \textbf{era} e aŋa era hai rau toa... | \gls of DIST time IDENT ART PL woman of PROX adult DIST IPFV weave EMPH CONT ACC ART hat DIST IPFV make DIST INS leaf sugarcane | \glt ‘At that time the older women here wove those hats which are made with sugarcane leaves....’

Knowledge Point: The same use of nei (though not in a noun phrase) is found in the expression pē nei ē ‘like this’, which introduces speech or thought (see (\ref{ex:4.231}–\ref{ex:4.232}) on p.~\pageref{ex:4.231}).\is{nei (proximal)!postnominal|)}
Content 1: \gll \ꞌIna koe ko taŋi mai \textbf{pē} \textbf{nei} \textbf{ē}: ko au te kai rivariva mai. | \gls NEG 2SG NEG.IPFV cry hither like PROX thus PROM 1SG ART eat good:RED hither | \glt ‘Don’t cry (thinking about the fact) that I am eating well’
Content 2: \gll Nu\ꞌu rahi te nu\ꞌu i mana\ꞌu \textbf{pē} \textbf{nei} \textbf{ē} ko tētere \ꞌana ki Tahiti. | \gls people many ART people PFV think like PROX thus PRF PL:run CONT to Tahiti | \glt ‘Many people thought that they had fled to Tahiti.’

Knowledge Point: Prenominal nei\is{nei (proximal)!demonstrative determiner|(} is similar in meaning to postnominal nei (\sectref{sec:4.6.3}): it indicates proximity in time, location or discourse. It may refer to something near the speaker as in \REF{ex:4.219}, something just mentioned as in \REF{ex:4.220}, or to a time close to the time of the preceding discourse as in \REF{ex:4.221}:
Content 1: \gll Te me\ꞌe aŋa mai nei e \textbf{nei} \textbf{vi\ꞌe}... | \gls ART thing do hither PROX AG PROX woman | \glt ‘What this woman (near the speaker) has done...’
Content 2: \gll Mai tētahi henua o te norte o Nueva Zelántia i oho mai ai ki \textbf{nei} \textbf{henua}. | \gls from other land of ART north of New Zealand PFV go hither PVP to PROX land | \glt ‘From other countries, to the north of New Zealand, they came to this island (= New Zealand).’
Content 3: \gll \ꞌE tako\ꞌa pa\ꞌi, \textbf{nei} \textbf{noho} \textbf{iŋa} kai rahi mai \ꞌā te me\ꞌe he \ꞌaurī ki nei. | \gls and also in_fact PROX stay NMLZ NEG.PFV much hither CONT ART thing PRED iron to PROX | \glt ‘And also, at this time (the period just mentioned), there was not much iron here.’

Knowledge Point: When preceded by a locative preposition, ira refers to a \textsc{location} which has been mentioned before: ‘that place, there’. In \REF{ex:4.233} ira refers back to ‘home’ in the previous clause, in \REF{ex:4.234} to ‘his country’:
Content 1: \gll I tu\ꞌu haka\ꞌou era a Mako\ꞌi ki te kona hare era, \textbf{\ꞌi} \textbf{ira} a Paepae. | \gls PFV arrive again DIST PROP Mako’i to ART place house DIST at ANA PROP Paepae | \glt ‘When Mako’i arrived home again, Paepae was there.’
Content 2: \gll He tu\ꞌu ki tō\ꞌona kāiŋa ko Ma\ꞌuŋa Terevaka. I tu\ꞌu era \textbf{ki} \textbf{ira}... | \gls NTR arrive to POSS.3SG.O homeland PROM Mount Terevaka PFV arrive DIST to ANA | \glt ‘He went to his own place, mount Terevaka. When he arrived there...’

Knowledge Point: One of the contexts in which locational\is{Locational} ira can be used, is in a relative clause\is{Clause!relative} with locative relativisation (see (\ref{ex:11.100}–\ref{ex:11.101}) on p.~\pageref{ex:11.100}).
Content 1: \gll He tu\ꞌu ki te kona \ob\textbf{\ꞌi} \textbf{ira} te honu\,\cb. | \gls NTR arrive to ART place {\db}at ANA ART turtle | \glt ‘They arrived at the place where the turtle was.’
Content 2: \gll ...mo oho ō\ꞌona ki Hiva ki te henua era \ob\textbf{mai} \textbf{ira} tō\ꞌona nu\ꞌu matu\ꞌa era i oho mai ai\,\cb. | \gls ~~~for go POSS.3SG.O to Hiva to ART land DIST {\db}from ANA POSS.3SG.O people parent DIST PFV go hither PVP | \glt ‘...to go to Hiva, the country from which his parents had come.’

Knowledge Point: Certain postnominal elements belonging to the predicate noun phrase occur after the subject: genitives as in \REF{ex:4.241}, relative clauses\is{Clause!relative} as in \REF{ex:4.242}.
Content 1: \gll He toru e\ꞌa iŋa atu \textbf{nei} o Tāpura Re\ꞌo. | \gls PRED three go_out NMLZ away PROX of Tapura Re’o | \glt ‘This is the third issue of (the newspaper) Tapura Re’o.’
Content 2: \gll Famiria hope\ꞌa \textbf{rā} oho mai mai kampō, mai \ꞌAnakena. | \gls family last DIST go hither from countryside from Anakena | \glt ‘That was the last family who came from the countryside, from Anakena.’

Knowledge Point: This means that the nominal predicate in (\ref{ex:4.241}–\ref{ex:4.243}) is split in two, and interrupted by the subject. Split predicates also occur with other pronominal subjects (\sectref{sec:9.2.5}).\is{Demonstrative}
Content 1: \gll He toru e\ꞌa iŋa atu \textbf{nei} o Tāpura Re\ꞌo. | \gls PRED three go_out NMLZ away PROX of Tapura Re’o | \glt ‘This is the third issue of (the newspaper) Tapura Re’o.’
Content 2: \gll \ob\ꞌAka \textbf{era}\,\cb \textbf{rā} \obo te parasa era o mu\ꞌa o te hare hāpī\,\cb. | \gls {\db}anchor DIST DIST {\db}of ART courtyard DIST of front of ART house learn | \glt ‘That is the anchor (which is) in the courtyard in front of the school.’

Knowledge Point: \textit{{\ꞌ}I} expresses stationary location: ‘in, on, at’. In this sense it is often followed by locationals\is{Locational} (\sectref{sec:3.6.2}). Here are examples where it is directly followed by a noun phrase: in (\ref{ex:4.244}–\ref{ex:4.245}) in a spatial sense, in \REF{ex:4.246} in a temporal sense.
Content 1: \gll He noho \textbf{\ꞌi} te hare o te huŋavai. | \gls NTR stay at ART house of ART parent_in_law | \glt ‘She stayed in the house of her in-laws.’
Content 2: \gll I poreko ena a koe \ꞌi Haŋa Roa. | \gls PFV born MED PROP 2SG at Hanga Roa | \glt ‘You were born in Hanga Roa.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{\ꞌI} tū hora era te taŋata ta\ꞌato\ꞌa ko ri\ꞌari\ꞌa tahi \ꞌana. | \gls at DEM time DIST ART person all PRF afraid all CONT | \glt ‘At that moment all the people were afraid.’

Knowledge Point: Possessive i is also found in proprietary clauses\is{Clause!proprietary} (see (\ref{ex:9.88}–\ref{ex:9.89}) on p.~\pageref{ex:9.88}).
Content 1: \gll I a tātou mau \ꞌā te pūai mo haka ma\ꞌitaki i te kāiŋa. | \gls at PROP 1PL.INCL really IDENT ART power for CAUS clean ACC ART homeland | \glt ‘Ours is the power to clean the island.’
Content 2: \gll I a mātou te kai ko piropiro \ꞌā. | \gls at PROP 1PL.EXCL ART food PRF rotten:RED CONT | \glt ‘Ours is the rotten food.’

Knowledge Point: With adjectives, i expresses the possessor\is{Possession} of a certain quality, i.e. the entity where the quality is located. Examples of this are the ko te X exclamative\is{Exclamative} construction (see (\ref{ex:10.82}–\ref{ex:10.83}) on p.~\pageref{ex:10.82}) and cases such as the following:
Content 1: \gll ¡Ko te nene \textbf{i} \textbf{te} \textbf{kiko}, \textbf{i} \textbf{te} \textbf{tātou} \textbf{kai}! | \gls ~PROM ART sweet at ART meat at ART 1PL.INCL food | \glt ‘How tasty is the meat, our food!’
Content 2: \gll ¡Ko te \ꞌaroha \textbf{i} \textbf{te} \textbf{rū\ꞌau} \textbf{era}! | \gls ~PROM ART pity at ART old_woman DIST | \glt ‘Poor old woman!’

Knowledge Point: \textit{{\ꞌ}I} is used to express causes. These causes can be events or states as in (\ref{ex:4.248}–\ref{ex:4.249}), but also non-human entities as in (\ref{ex:4.250}–\ref{ex:4.251}). Cf. the discussion on agentive i in \sectref{sec:8.6.4.7}.
Content 1: \gll ¡He mate ta\ꞌa māhaki \textbf{\ꞌi} \textbf{te} \textbf{maruaki}! | \gls ~NTR die POSS.2SG.A companion at ART hunger | \glt ‘Your friend dies from hunger!’
Content 2: \gll He viriviri a Torometi \textbf{\ꞌi} \textbf{te} \textbf{kata}. | \gls NTR roll:RED PROP Torometi at ART laugh | \glt ‘Torometi fell down from laughing.’
Content 3: \gll He hati te ŋao o \ꞌOto \ꞌUta \textbf{\ꞌi} \textbf{te} \textbf{pureva}. | \gls NTR break ART neck of Oto Uta at ART rock | \glt ‘The neck of (the statue) Oto Uta broke by/from the rock.’
Content 4: \gll Ku ŋarepe \ꞌā te kahu \textbf{\ꞌi} \textbf{te} \textbf{\ꞌua}. | \gls PRF wet CONT ART clothes at ART rain | \glt ‘The clothes got soaked by the rain.’

Knowledge Point: Causes are also expressed with the preposition \textit{{\ꞌ}o}, but there is a difference. \textit{{\ꞌ}I} is used in situations where cause and effect are closely linked, i.e. for direct causes which automatically lead to a certain effect. In \REF{ex:4.249}, for example, laughter is not only the cause of falling down, but also accompanies the falling down: ‘He fell while laughing, he fell down with laughter’. Similarly, in \REF{ex:4.248}, hunger it not only the cause of death, but hunger and death go together. In some cases – such as \REF{ex:4.249} – cause and effect are so closely linked, that the \textit{{\ꞌ}i}\nobreakdash-marked constituent is similar to a circumstantial clause. \textit{{\ꞌ}O}, on the other hand, is used in situations where cause and effect are less closely linked. Here are a few examples:
Content 1: \gll He viriviri a Torometi \textbf{\ꞌi} \textbf{te} \textbf{kata}. | \gls NTR roll:RED PROP Torometi at ART laugh | \glt ‘Torometi fell down from laughing.’
Content 2: \gll ¡He mate ta\ꞌa māhaki \textbf{\ꞌi} \textbf{te} \textbf{maruaki}! | \gls ~NTR die POSS.2SG.A companion at ART hunger | \glt ‘Your friend dies from hunger!’
Content 3: \gll He viriviri a Torometi \textbf{\ꞌi} \textbf{te} \textbf{kata}. | \gls NTR roll:RED PROP Torometi at ART laugh | \glt ‘Torometi fell down from laughing.’

Knowledge Point: Ki is often followed by a locational\is{Locational} indicating the direction in which the movement takes place (see e.g. \REF{ex:3.133} on p.~\pageref{ex:3.133}).
Content 1: \gll He uru te kurī ki roto i te hare. | \gls textsc{ntr} enter ART cat to inside at ART house | \glt ‘The cat entered into (lit. to inside) the house.’

Knowledge Point: Ki is used when a referent is oriented towards an object, even when no movement towards this object is involved: in \REF{ex:4.265} the tree bark is exposed to the sun, but not moved towards the sun.
Content 1: \gll Ki oti he to\ꞌo mai, he tauaki \textbf{ki} te ra\ꞌā, he haka pakapaka. | \gls when finish NTR take hither NTR dry_in_sun to ART sun NTR CAUS dry:RED | \glt ‘After that they take (the tree bark) and put it in the sun to dry.’

Knowledge Point: In a temporal sense, ki indicates the end of a stretch of time: ‘until’, as in \REF{ex:4.266}.\footnote{\label{fn:230}The preverbal marker ki has the same function (see examples (\ref{ex:11.196}–\ref{ex:11.197}) on p.~\pageref{ex:11.196}).} In this sense, ki may be reinforced by \textit{{\ꞌ}ātā}\is{ata ‘until’@{\ꞌ}ātā ‘until’} ({\textless} Sp. hasta ‘until’) as in \REF{ex:4.267}.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌO ira e ko hakarē a au i a koe \textbf{ki} tō\ꞌoku hope\ꞌara\ꞌa. | \gls because_of ANA IPFV NEG.IPFV leave PROP 1SG ACC ART 2SG to POSS.1SG.O end | \glt ‘Therefore I will not leave you till the end of my days.’
Content 2: \gll He tiaki \textbf{ki} hū tahi te hukahuka. | \gls NTR wait to burn all ART firewood:RED | \glt ‘They wait until all the firewood is burned.’
Content 3: \gll He noho rō atu \ꞌai o tū nu\ꞌu era \ꞌi ira \textbf{ki} ora riva o te mata o Māhina Tea. | \gls NTR stay EMPH away SUBS of DEM people DIST at there to live good of ART eye of Mahina Tea | \glt ‘The people stayed there until Mahina Tea’s eyes had healed well.’
Content 4: \gll Mai rā hora \textbf{\ꞌātā} \textbf{ki} te hora nei kai e\ꞌa haka\ꞌou e tahi Rapa Nui. | \gls from DIST time until to ART time PROX NEG.PFV go_out again NUM one Rapa Nui | \glt ‘From that time until now, not one Rapa Nui left (the island) anymore.’

Knowledge Point: Ki has a wide range of metaphorical extensions; it is the default preposition for semantic roles like Recipient, Beneficiary and Goal (\sectref{sec:8.8.2}) as in \REF{ex:4.268}. Ki is used to indicate an opinion or point of view: ‘according to’, as in \REF{ex:4.269}. In addition, ki marks the object of middle verbs\is{Verb!middle} (\sectref{sec:8.6.4.2}).
Content 1: \gll He va\ꞌai a nua i te kai ki a koro. | \gls NTR give PROP Mum ACC ART food to PROP Dad | \glt ‘Mum gave the food to Dad.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ki} te kī o te nu\ꞌu te repa nei ko Ure \ꞌa Vai \ꞌa Nuhe he kope nehenehe. | \gls to ART say of ART people ART young_man PROX PROM Ure a Vai a Nuhe PRED person beautiful | \glt ‘According to (lit. to the say of) the people, young Ure a Vai a Nuhe was a handsome man.’

Knowledge Point: In a temporal sense, pe is used with the locational\is{Locational} \textit{mu{\ꞌ}a}\is{mua ‘front’@mu{\ꞌ}a ‘front’} ‘front’ to refer to a period of time in the future, or posterior\is{Posteriority} to a time of reference (see (\ref{ex:3.153}–\ref{ex:3.154}) on p.~\pageref{ex:3.153}).
Content 1: \gll Mai te hora nei \textbf{pe} \textbf{mu\ꞌa}, e ko take\ꞌa haka\ꞌou au e koe. | \gls from ART time PROX toward front IPFV NEG.IPFV see again 1SG AG 2SG | \glt ‘From now on, you won’t see me anymore.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Pe} \textbf{mu\ꞌa} ka oho ena, he haka aŋa rō au i te hare. | \gls toward front CNTG go MED NTR CAUS make EMPH 1SG ACC ART house | \glt ‘Later, I will have a house built.’

Knowledge Point: \is{pe ‘towards’}Pe may also indicate an approximate location as in \REF{ex:4.276}, or an approximate time as in \REF{ex:4.277}:
Content 1: \gll Te me\ꞌe hau mau o te rahi he mā\ꞌea, \textbf{pe} \textbf{ruŋa} \textbf{pe} \textbf{raro} o te ma\ꞌuŋa. | \gls ART thing exceed really of ART much PRED stone toward above toward below of ART mountain | \glt ‘What’s really abundant (on the island) are stones, up and down the mountain.’
Content 2: \gll I ahiahi era \textbf{pe} \textbf{te} hora toru, he turu mai tū Tamy era. | \gls PFV afternoon DIST toward ART time three NTR go_down hither DEM Tamy DIST | \glt ‘Around three o’clock in the afternoon, Tamy went down.’

Knowledge Point: A often indicates a general direction; this direction is expressed by a locational\is{Locational} (such as \textit{mu{\ꞌ}a} in \REF{ex:4.282}), but there is no second referent involved with respect to which this movement takes place.
Content 1: \gll He oho, he ao \textbf{a} mu\ꞌa, he pū \textbf{a} mu\ꞌa. | \gls NTR go NTR rush by front NTR come by front | \glt ‘They went, they came forward, rushed forward.’

Subsection: The benefactive prepositions mo and mā\label{sec:4.7.7
Knowledge Point: A benefactive relation is in fact a possessive relationship in which a possessee is destined/intended for the possessor\is{Possession}.\footnote{\label{fn:235}In Polynesian linguistics, these forms are sometimes characterised as “irrealis\is{Irrealis} possessives” (see e.g. \citealt{Clark2000Possessive}; \citealt[48]{Wilson1982}): they indicate not-yet realised possession, in contrast to the “realis\is{Realis} possessives” starting with n- or Ø (see Footnote \ref{fn:290} on p.~\pageref{fn:290}). The likely origin of the m{}-forms is an irrealis\is{Irrealis} marker m- \citep[115]{Clark1976}.} Whether mo or mā is used, depends on the relationship between the prospective possessor\is{Possession} and possessee, as discussed in \sectref{sec:6.3.2}: mā is used when the possessor\is{Possession} has control, authority or responsibility over the possessee, mo in all other cases. Thus, mā is used for possessions over which the possessor\is{Possession} has control, as in \REF{ex:4.284}. Mo is used for means of transport as in \REF{ex:4.285}.
Content 1: \gll He aŋa e tō\ꞌona matu\ꞌa vahine i te manu parau \textbf{mā\ꞌana}. | \gls NTR make AG POSS.3SG.O parent female ACC ART bird paper BEN.3SG.A | \glt ‘His mother made a paper bird for him.’
Content 2: \gll He pu\ꞌa i te hoi e tahi \textbf{mō\ꞌona}, e tahi mo te matu\ꞌa. | \gls NTR cover ACC ART horse NUM one BEN.3SG.O NUM one for ART parent | \glt ‘He saddled one horse for himself, one for the priest.’

Subsection: The benefactive prepositions mo and mā\label{sec:4.7.7
Knowledge Point: \is{Benefactive preposition}Mo may also indicate a participant from whose perspective the event expressed in the clause is true: ‘for X, as far as X is concerned’.\footnote{\label{fn:236}Cf. the use of ki to express a point of view (\sectref{sec:4.7.3}).} This use may have been influenced by \ili{Spanish} para. In \REF{ex:4.288}, the things described in the preceding context are news, not necessary for everyone, but for the person mentioned: as far as he is concerned, they are news. In \REF{ex:4.289}, the clause expresses a point of view which is true for the person expressed with mo:
Content 1: \gll \ꞌE te ŋā me\ꞌe ta\ꞌato\ꞌa nei he parau \ꞌāpī \textbf{mō\ꞌona}. | \gls and ART PL thing all PROX PRED word new BEN.3SG.O | \glt ‘And all of this was news for him.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Mō\ꞌoku} \ꞌina he \ꞌati te noho mai o rāua \ꞌi te kona era. | \gls BEN.1SG.O NEG PRED problem ART stay hither of 3PL at ART place DIST | \glt ‘For me (as far as I am concerned), it is no problem if they live there.’

Knowledge Point: First of all, pē is usually followed by the predicate marker he\is{he (nominal predicate marker)},\footnote{\label{fn:238}Interestingly, the same is true for the preposition me ‘like’ in \ili{Hawaiian}, \ili{Marquesan} and \ili{Māori} (\sectref{sec:5.3.3}).} not only when the compared entity is generic as in \REF{ex:4.291}, but also when it is a single, identifiable\is{Identifiability} entity as in \REF{ex:4.292}:
Content 1: \gll He u\ꞌi atu a Eva ko te me\ꞌe \textbf{pē} \textbf{he} tiare \ꞌā ka \ꞌī. | \gls NTR look away PROP Eva PROM ART thing like PRED flower IDENT CNTG full | \glt ‘Eva saw something like flowers, in great numbers
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Pē} \textbf{he} korohu\ꞌa era ko Iovani \ꞌIti\ꞌiti te \ꞌāriŋa. | \gls like PRED old_man DIST PROM Iovani Iti’iti ART face | \glt ‘His face (looks) like the old man Iovani Iti’iti.’

Knowledge Point: Occasionally pē is followed by a t-determiner as in \REF{ex:4.294}, or a proper noun or pronoun as in \REF{ex:4.295}:
Content 1: \gll ¿\textbf{Pē} \textbf{tū} huru \ꞌā te kī iŋa o te ŋā vānaŋa nei? | \gls ~like DEM manner IDENT ART say NMLZ of ART PL word PROX | \glt ‘Are these words pronounced the same way (lit. is the saying like that [same] way)?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Pē} \textbf{ia} \ꞌā te huru. | \gls like 3SG IDENT ART manner | \glt ‘He looks like him.’

Knowledge Point: In modern Rapa Nui, pē also expresses the category to which someone belongs. In \REF{ex:4.296} below, \textit{pē he {\ꞌ}ōtare} does not mean that the speaker resembles an orphan, but that he is an orphan. This usage may be influenced by \ili{Spanish} como.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌIna ō\ꞌoku matu\ꞌa, \ꞌo ira a au e noho nei \textbf{pē} he \ꞌōtare. | \gls NEG POSS.1SG.O parent because_of ANA PROP 1SG IPFV stay PROX like PRED orphan | \glt ‘I don’t have parents, therefore I live as an orphan.’

Knowledge Point: As discussed in \sectref{sec:4.7.1}, hai is not followed by a determiner, but by a bare noun. This correlates with the meaning of hai, which tends to occur with non-specific\is{Specific reference!non-specific reference} referents as in \REF{ex:4.297} above. Occasionally, however, hai is followed by pronouns or proper nouns\is{Noun!proper} as in \REF{ex:4.298}, or by definite nouns (preceded by a demonstrative) as in \REF{ex:4.299}:
Content 1: \gll He pu\ꞌapu\ꞌa \textbf{hai} pāoa; he mate. | \gls NTR beat:RED INS club NTR die | \glt ‘They beat her with a club and she died.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Hai} Eugenio \ꞌi te pū\ꞌoko e aŋa era ananake. | \gls INS Eugenio at ART head IPFV work DIST together | \glt ‘With Eugenio at the head they worked together.’
Content 3: \gll E puru rō \ꞌā te \ꞌāriŋa ararua \textbf{hai} tū paratoa era o rāua. | \gls IPFV close EMPH CONT ART face the_two INS DEM coat DIST of 3PL | \glt ‘The two covered their faces with their coat.’

Knowledge Point: The semantic range of hai is large. It may indicate the instrument or material with which an action is done, as in \REF{ex:4.297} above and the following examples:
Content 1: \gll He pu\ꞌapu\ꞌa \textbf{hai} pāoa; he mate. | \gls NTR beat:RED INS club NTR die | \glt ‘They beat her with a club and she died.’

Knowledge Point: Hai may mark various kinds of noun phrases which are in some way instrumental to the action, such as the price paid as in \REF{ex:4.302}, or the language spoken as in \REF{ex:4.303}.
Content 1: \gll E ko ho\ꞌo atu ki a koe \textbf{hai} moni tire, ni \textbf{hai} torare... | \gls IPFV NEG.IPFV trade away to PROP 2SG INS money Chile nor INS dollar | \glt ‘They wouldn’t pay you with Chilean money, nor with dollars...’
Content 2: \gll A au i haŋa ai mo vānaŋa atu \textbf{hai} \ꞌarero o tātou \ꞌā. | \gls PROP 1SG PFV want PVP for talk away INS tongue of 1PL.INCL IDENT | \glt ‘I wanted to speak in our own language.’

Knowledge Point: The NP marked with hai may also be a resource which is needed but not found yet. This sense is found with verbs of asking or searching as in \REF{ex:4.306}, but also in other contexts as in \REF{ex:4.307}:
Content 1: \gll He nono\ꞌi e te korohu\ꞌa nei \textbf{hai} haraoa. | \gls NTR request AG ART old_man PROX INS bread | \glt ‘This old man asked for bread.’
Content 2: \gll He e\ꞌa tau vi\ꞌe era mai tō\ꞌona hare \textbf{hai} ahi. | \gls NTR go_out DEM woman DIST from POSS.3SG.O house INS fire | \glt ‘The woman left her house (to look) for fire(wood).’

Knowledge Point: \textit{{\ꞌ}Ai} is a deictic particle (\sectref{sec:4.5.4.1.2}). Occasionally it is used as a preposition to point at something which is at a certain distance: ‘there at/in/on...’. Like other prepositions, it may be followed by locationals\is{Locational} as in (\ref{ex:4.308}–\ref{ex:4.309}) or nouns\is{Noun!common} as in \REF{ex:4.310}:
Content 1: \gll E pāpā, ka u\ꞌi koe \textbf{\ꞌai} \textbf{ruŋa} i te ma\ꞌuŋa te moa e rua. | \gls VOC father IMP look 2SG there_at above at ART mountain ART chicken NUM two | \glt ‘Father, look, there on the mountain are two chickens.’
Content 2: \gll Te pūtē \textbf{\ꞌai} \textbf{roto} i te hare. | \gls ART sack there_at inside at ART house | \glt ‘The bag is there inside the house.’
Content 3: \gll \ꞌE \textbf{\ꞌai} \textbf{te} \textbf{pā\ꞌeŋa} \textbf{era} a mātou. | \gls and there_at ART side DIST PROP 1PL.EXCL | \glt ‘And we were there on that side.’

Subsubsection: Ko in lists and in isolation\label{sec:4.7.11.1
Knowledge Point: Ko is used to mark items in a list. These items may be proper nouns\is{Noun!proper} or common nouns\is{Noun!common} with definite reference. The list may be isolated from the syntactic context as in \REF{ex:4.320}, but it may also have a syntactic role in the clause: in \REF{ex:4.321} the noun phrases introduced by ko are direct object, yet they are marked with ko rather than the accusative marker\is{i (accusative marker)} i.\footnote{\label{fn:241}Common nouns\is{Noun!common} in lists may also be marked with he (\sectref{sec:5.3.4.1}).}
Content 1: \gll ...i tētere ai \ꞌi ruŋa i te vaka te nu\ꞌu nei: \textbf{ko} Parano, \textbf{ko} Hoi Hiva, \textbf{ko} Mā\ꞌaŋa, \textbf{ko} Feri \ꞌe \textbf{ko} Tira. | \gls ~~~PFV PL:run PVP at above at ART boat ART people PROX PROM Parano PROM Hoi Hiva PROM Ma’anga PROM Feri and PROM Tira | \glt ‘(On 2 March 1944) the following people fled by boat: Parano, Hoi Hiva, Ma’anga, Feri and Tira.’
Content 2: \gll He \ꞌapa tahi \textbf{ko} te ŋā poki, \textbf{ko} te hare, \textbf{ko} te me\ꞌe ta\ꞌato\ꞌa. | \gls NTR gather all PROM ART PL child PROM ART house PROM ART thing all | \glt ‘She gathered all the children, the house, everything.’

Subsubsection: Ko in lists and in isolation\label{sec:4.7.11.1
Knowledge Point: Ko also marks noun phrases used in isolation, i.e. without a syntactic context. In a running text, examples of isolated noun phrases are hard to detect, as a noun phrase which seems to be isolated, may actually be the predicate of a nominal clause\is{Clause!nominal} with implied subject (see (\ref{ex:9.15}–\ref{ex:9.16}) on p.~\pageref{ex:9.15}). Clearer examples of isolated noun phrases are found in titles of stories and other texts. The following examples show that isolated pronouns and proper nouns\is{Noun!proper} are marked ko, while common nouns\is{Noun!common} in isolation are marked with either ko or he (\sectref{sec:5.3.4.1}).
Content 1: \gll —¿Ko ai koe? —\textbf{Ko} \textbf{au} \textbf{\ꞌana}. | \gls ~~~~~PROM who 2SG ~~~PROM 1SG IDENT | \glt ‘—Who are you? —It’s me.’
Content 2: \gll —Me\ꞌe era ko Tito. —\ꞌĒē. \textbf{Ko} \textbf{ia}. | \gls ~~~thing~ DIST PROM Tito ~~~yes PROM 3SG | \glt ‘—That one (in the picture) is Tito. —Yes. It’s him.’

Knowledge Point: In a number of cases, ko has become lexicalised, i.e. become part of a word or expression. In these expressions, ko is always used, even in syntactic contexts in which it would not occur otherwise. One example is the construction ko ŋā kope ‘the people, the guys’ (\sectref{sec:5.5.2}). Another example is \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e ko {\ꞌ}iti}, which acts as a frozen expression meaning ‘not a few, a considerable number, many’:\footnote{\label{fn:242}All other adjectives are negated by \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e} without the use of ko (see \REF{ex:10.147} on p.~\pageref{ex:10.147}).}
Content 1: \gll A Hiero poki \textbf{ta\ꞌe} porio ni \textbf{ta\ꞌe} pāpaku. | \gls PROP Hiero child CONNEG fat nor CONNEG thin | \glt ‘Hiero was neither a fat nor a skinny child.’

Knowledge Point: Thirdly, the word tetu ‘huge, enormous’ is usually preceded by ko. This combination ko tetu is lexicalised, that is, its use cannot be predicted from ko + tetu.\footnote{\label{fn:243}Ko in ko tetu may have found its origin in the exclamatory ko, discussed in sec. \sectref{sec:10.4.2}.} Ko tetu is used very flexibly: as an adjective modifying a noun, but also freestanding as in \REF{ex:4.328}.
Content 1: \gll Nā, te vave e tahi ko uru mai \ꞌā \textbf{ko} \textbf{tetu}. | \gls MED ART wave NUM one PRF enter hither CONT PROM huge | \glt ‘Look, there comes a huge wave.’
